text: I'm an assistant professor here at HBS.
Sorry, it's Harvard Business School.
[laughter]
Okay,
one more time.
Hi, I am Natalia Garbiras-Diaz.
I'm an assistant professor in the
Business, Government & the International Economy Unit
at Harvard Business School.
My research interests
lie at the intersection
of economics and political science.
I study two specific areas.
One, how to restore the rule of law
in post-conflict settings,
and two, how to enhance
the quality of governance. In particular,

how to improve the linkage
between citizens
and politicians.
Growing up in Colombia,

which is where I'm from,
gave me a lot of perspective.

And since I was a child, I had the chance
to go to different parts of the country.

And that made me realize that
people experience very different realities.
Not only do those different realities
shape the opportunities that people have,
but also can have deep consequences
for many generations after them.

I wanted to understand what shapes
those opportunities

and how can we improve the
livelihood of many people.
Understanding how to improve citizens’
commitment to democracy
necessarily requires us
to understand how can we improve

the promises
that democracy makes to these citizens.
It is really important to understand
what are some of the limitations
that politicians have when they really
want to deliver to their citizens.
What are some of the interventions
or some of the institutions
that really facilitate
accountability, governance,
and the delivery of the goods and services
that citizens care about.
I'm currently in discussions to implement
a project around an election intervention
in a country in Latin America
that seeks to train elected politicians
on how to improve

their managerial skills
and also their commitment to democracy.
Again, trying to understand
if these types of trainings can help
or improve the delivery of services.
Checks and balances are important,
negotiations with the opposition,
how to deliberate, how to deliver, how to communicate.
I brought a booklet, this one.

And it is one of 13 books
that were published by
the Truth Commission in Colombia.
This one in particular is called

Resiliencia,
which in English means “resilience.”

And I really like this word
because it reflects
the faces behind people who are suffering
violence, lack of opportunities.
I have always been very impressed

by the way in which people cope
with those adversities.
I really want to keep that in mind,

the faces, behind the topics
that I study

because ultimately,
this is the people that we want to impact.

This has really motivated my,
my passion to be able to understand

how can we actually contribute,
to the lives of these

really, really resilient
people that deserve best.
